results.title: The gay men's guide to safer sex (E)
results.creator_credit: James MacKay, Terrence Higgins Trust, Basilisk Productions and David Lewis
results.brief_description: A documentary produced by gay men for gay men offering information on HIV and AIDS and exploring the boundaries and possibilities of safe consensual sex. Using a straightforward presentation sexual information is offered in an unintimidating manner. Includes information on using condoms effectively, how to have safe oral sex and how to avoid transmission of blood and semen in S/M sex play. WARNING: CONTAINS EXPLICIT SEXUAL MATERIAL.

results.title: The Gay divorcee
results.creator_credit: Pandro S. Berman and Mark Sandrich
results.brief_description: Adapted from the 1932 Cole Porter musical. The plot of “The Gay Divorcee”, rooted in mistaken identity is delightful. The script is sophisticated and bright and the cast is impeccable for comedy of this nature. Comparable to the best of Busby Berkeley and the most ingenious ballets of Gene Kelly, The Continental” dance routine is sufficient to turn “The Gay Divorcee into one of your most thrilling musical experiences. Stars Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers.

results.title: The Gay deceivers
results.creator_credit: Joe Solomon, Fanfare Film Productions and Bruce Kessler
results.brief_description: Late sixties comedy about two young heterosexual men who pretend to be a gay couple in order to dodge the draft. Although the Army rejects the two, the recruiting officer questions their story and they are forced to move together into an all-gay L.A. apartment complex to add weight to their lie. Humour revolves around the comedy of misunderstandings that ensue involving the stereotypically ‘campy’ residents of the apartment complex. Though based on a homophobic premise, and aimed at a straight audience, the film is of interest as a naive camp curiosity and contains a few genuinely funny moments (and many unintentional ones). Along with “Boys in the Band” this was one of the only American 1960s mainstream films to feature homosexual characters. Cast includes Kevin Coughlin and Larry Casey.

results.title: The Gauntlet
results.creator_credit: Robert Daley, Warner Bros Pictures, Malpaso Company and Clint Eastwood
results.brief_description: Clint Eastwood runs ‘The Gauntlet’ into an explosive piece of movie making that lives up to its title with a vengeance. He plays a burnt out Phoenix cop on an assignment to bring back from Las Vegas a ‘nothing witness for a nothing trial’ (Locke) which seems just another meaningless task in a meaningless life. Until the fireworks start! Trapped by treachery on both sides of the law, the two are forced through a deadly obstacle course of raging gunfire, blazing cars, swooping helicopters, murderous ambushes, crazed bikers and crooked police. With non-stop action and special effects that will blast you to the back of your seat, including a ferocious finale in which an armoured bus is shot to smithereens with more than 8,000 bullets (8000 bullets and none hit the tyres!). Leave the driving to Eastwood, sit back and enjoy the ride.

results.title: The Gathering flame [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Roland Beckett, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Don Murray
results.brief_description: The sea has a certain fascination for Australians. Although it is a large dry contitnent, most Australians live close to the sea. This film makes magnificent use of the sea as a background to the work of designing, building and servicing the variety of navigational aids off the coast of Australia, particularly the work of the ships of Cape Pillar, Cape Morton and Cape Don. An interesting split screen effect has been employed in this fast moving colourful documenatry. Commentary by John Laws.

results.title: The Gathering drum
results.creator_credit: D. Keith Carlson and WGBH Educational Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Kindergarten child series”.
At the beginning of the kindergarten day children are encouraged to move freely and choose from a variety of play objects. A drumbeat then brings them together to be introduced to the day’s activities.

results.title: The Gathering
results.creator_credit: Harry R Sherman, Hanna-Barbera Productions and Randal Kleiser
results.brief_description: This feature length film made for television is a Christmas story with a difference. Adam Thornton (Ed Asner) walked out on his family years ago to focus his energies on his business career, leaving a wife and four children - two sons and two daughters. Thornton is a gruff, hard-headed man who finds out just before Christmas that he has a terminal illness and only a few weeks to live. On telling his estranged wife, Kate (Maureen Stapleton), it is agreed that a family reunion should take place over Christmas, but only on the proviso that his imminent death is not disclosed to his now four adult children. The story avoids a “sugary-sweet” tone by exploring the interaction between Thornton and each of his family members as he attempts to tentatively reconcile the past. He soon discovers that not everyone is totally forgiving but it is his wife who is the anchor, who holds the family together. Ed Asner and Maureen Stapleton are excellent in their roles and are accompanied by a very able support cast including Sarah Cunningham, Bruce Davison, Veronica Hamel, Gregory Harrison, Lawrence Pressman, John Randolph, Gail Strickland, Stephanie Zimbalist. (Awards: Emmy for Outstanding Special - Drama or Comedy, 1978)

results.title: The Gas turbine
results.creator_credit: Shell Film Unit and Peter De Normanville
results.brief_description: The gas turbine is a heat engine, the simplest and smoothest running yet devised. All heat engines burn fuel, change a small part of the heat produced into energy, and waste the rest through the exhaust. In the gas turbine, rushing torrent of hot high-pressure exhaust gas is the turbine’s source of power.

results.title: The Gary Crew video
results.creator_credit: Christine McCaul Gleitzman, Mark Waters and Insight Profile
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Insight profile”.
Gary Crew explains how he developed the ideas behind his award winning novels. He takes you back through his childhood and early life to the buildings and landscapes which were the inspiration for the settings of many of his books. He explains how the right ‘setting’ for a novel is as important as a good storyline, and how to develop any place, no matter how boring, into something special.

results.title: The Garden of the Finzi-Continis = Il Giardino dei Finzi-Contini
results.creator_credit: CCC Filmkunst, Documento Films, Gianni Hecht Lucari, Arthur Cohn and Vittorio De Sica
results.brief_description: Made towards the end of his life, de Sica’s “The Garden of the Finzi-Continis” is one of the Italian director’s finest achievements. In this movie de Sica turns his gaze away from the urban working class lives that dominated his neo-realist cinema, and instead focuses on the lives of an aristocratic Jewish family leading up to the tragedy of World War II. Based on Giorgio Bassini’s acclaimed novel of the same name, the film details the experiences of love, family and politics as seen through the eyes of the adults and the adolescents in the Finzi-Contini family. The children attempt to make their mansion a refuge against fascism, a perpetual romantic space to re-live their childhood games and preoccupations. The adults, in turn, hope that by accommodating to the increasingly humiliating “race-laws” they will buy time and live to see the restoration of the old social order. But as Italy joins Germany in war, all their attempts prove futile against the savage anti-Semitism of fascism. In the film’s devastating concluding passage, the tragedy of European twentieth-century history is conveyed in the stark faces of the family, stripped of their luxuries and belongings; stripped of their illusions and their hope. The film is a loving remembrance of a specifically Italian Jewish history and culture: de Sica’s ability to immerse us in the textures and colours of a vanquished past is one of this film’s greatest achievements. It’s dignified simplicity in presenting the horror of the Holocaust makes it one of the most eloquent of anti-war films. (Awards: Winner of the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film. Winner of the Golden Bear at the Venice Film Festival. With Dominique Sanda, Helmut Berger) In Italian with English subtitles.
